Posts.Content: Hi Binny I had a bone scan in Nov after experiencing regular discomfort - like pressure - and pain on the right side of my chest for nearly a year.  My cancer was diagnosed on the left side (lumpectomy, lymph nodes removed, mastectomy, chemo & rads from Jan - Sept) and my right side was given all clear.  My GP requested the bone scan as a process of 'elimination' given my recent history - and that's how I had to force myself to look at it.  Having the bone scan did not mean 'oh s&^t we need to check for more cancer'.  It meant patient not happy - let's see what else is going on...... a difficult mind shift given our experience to date but I had to hold on to that.  And I hope it might help you too.  The procedure is exactly as George & Jackie described.  I found it a piece of cake after chemo.  The injection was the only slight discomfort.  There was a couple of hours hanging around but so what - and the scan doesn't touch you so nothing there.  Certainly didn't feel claustrophobic. My scan came back clear.  Still don't know exact cause - current thinking something muscular -  but cancer has been eliminated. So big hug as I do know how worrying it can be when we now feel any discomfort or pain.  But the bone scan is straightforward and, in our cases, essential.  We need to know what's going on. Take care of yourself. Anne-Marie x
Posts.Title: Need some help here girls....

Posts.Content: Hi there.  One thing to remember is that you'll be getting increasingly tired as you go through the treatments.  Although I managed Tax overall better than FEC I could feel it was getting harder and harder to just generally cope with the days.  And with that come all sorts of emotions, in particular weeping buckets.   And it's as if a sort of cabin fever begins to set in as the chemo sessions go on. But the end is in sight!  Do you have something nice to look forward to?  Have you a reward lined up for yourself?  I wanted the chemo all over by the time my son's school holidays were due to start last summer. Keep going.  You're almost there!  Big hugs.  Anne-Marie xx
Posts.Title: Can't stop crying

Posts.Content: Hi there As mistymoley said - the pain could be any number of things.  After all my treatment last year I was still experiencing intermittent pain and discomfort in my chest on the right side (mx was left).  Was really worried something dreadful was going on and had bone scan and chest x-ray.  Nothing sinister showed up.  It's still a mystery but the pain has eased off in past few weeks.  So it's not always bad news but you are right to be vigilant.  By the way, the bone scan was very straightforward.  Another bloomin' injection but that was the only very minor discomfort.  Hope these posts are easing your worries a little.  Understand perfectly how you are feeling and on top of it all you have your grandson to think about.  Hope everything turns out ok and sending you a big hug. Anne-Marie x
Posts.Title: Bone Scan

Posts.Content: Keep out of the sun during tax.  I found this out a bit too late last year and found my face and hands covered in hot itchy rash after being to the park with my son on one of my better days after 1st tax.  My lips also swelled up.  Onc team was a little confused but extra steriods and staying out of sunlight for the next 7 weeks helped.  For the rest of the summer I covered myself in factor 50 cream and had no further problems.   Sincerely hope your rash doesn't get any worse - you've enough to contend with.... Good luck Anne-Marie x
Posts.Title: Red neck

Posts.Content: Absolutely unacceptable!  Compassion, gentleness, reassurance are critical elements of treatment. And if we d9n't give feedback, nothing will change.  I've been in hospital all week waiting for transfer to Nottingham for neurology and the nurses at Derby have been excellent.  Real stars.  Can't let poor experiences knock us back. Thanks George & Jackie about PALs....hadn't thought about approaching re my experience last year.  i'm not looking for trouble but I feel the need to be far more involved, knowledgeable and able to question treatment plans, communication - or lack of it. Louise - hope you get some strength from G & J's suggestion..  Take care.  Anne-Marie x
Posts.Title: ECG feel exposed

Posts.Content: Thank you!  what a hoot... just mulling over how you could go viral with this.  Pam's at the Edinburgh Festival this year - she reads this in support of Macmillan?? Anne-Marie xx
Posts.Title: I Wish I'd Felt Both Of Me Tits - (adapted from Pam Ayers)

Posts.Content: I was totally knocked out too on first FEC.  Couldn't get out of bed and took me a full week to get back on my feet.  I also, unfortunately, felt very ill to the extent my Onc reduced the dose slightly next time around. So, I'm with you.  We're still Superwomen - I just shop online and enjoy my house being untidy for a change. Take care Anne-Marie x p.s. weirdly I seem to be managing Tax better than FEC.  Hasn't knocked me out nearly as much.
Posts.Title: Day 7 Am I a softy?

Posts.Content: Due final chemo next week - fingers crossed (never thought I'd say that!) But while I've lost 95% of hair on my head, it's still growing on my legs!!  Even shaved them this morning.... Now THAT is unfair! (lol) Big hugs to everyone starting out on chemo.  Thinking of you. Anne-Marie x
Posts.Title: Outrageous!

Posts.Content: hi i'm about 8 months post chemo and the tightness does ease.  i also can't see the 'dip' much in my foreman where the damaged vein is.  so don't know veins fully recover but discomfort does go. hope this helps a little...... Anne-Marie x
Posts.Title: Damaged veins

Posts.Content: Hi - I can't help with the chemo/chickenpox question but just wanted to add that ViraSoothe was a really good product to calm the itching when my son had chickenpox.  You may have it already but if not it's available at all supermarkets.   Like you I've had chickenpox but was also offered a vaccination against shingles, which apparently can develop if adults are exposed to chickenpox.  Perhaps something you could ask about at a later date. Really sorry can't offer better advice but hope you are ok and your daughter recovers soon. Anne-Marie x
Posts.Title: Chickenpox!!!

Posts.Content: Hi Purple Fox.  You were right.  I don't want to sound too blase but so far rads have been a breeze compared to chemo.  I'm half way through and even managed to sleep in a tent on my own last week at a festival.  Today I was at the top of a ferris wheel at a funfair with my son.  On the one hand I think I'm slightly mad...on the other, it's just wonderful to get out and do things again! Hope your camping plans...went to plan!
Posts.Title: For anyone about to start or going through chemo.....

Posts.Content: I'm just about at the end of the 3rd week of my final chemo (3 FEC/3 Tax)  and today I've had the first day when I've felt 'normal' for so many months.   I wanted to share this with anyone who is about to start chemo or going through it to try to give you some reassurance that yes, it's a tough treatment but if I can get through it, you can too.  And it's such a wonderful relief when you can begin to enjoy various things again. Today I was able to take my son, who's only 7, and a couple of his friends to the park, have lunch, get the paddling pool out, etc - all normal things for a mum to do.  And it felt so good.  I'm knackered but that's ok.  I still have 3 wks of rads to go next month but feel and hope that that will be easier going than the chemo and mastectomy (and boy, was I traumatised about that!!). So, for anyone who can't sleep tonight at the thought of what's ahead of them, please take heart - if utter wimps like me can battle my way through, you will too.  Take care everyone. Anne-Marie x
Posts.Title: For anyone about to start or going through chemo.....

Posts.Content: Ah, the hair thing.... It was/is the biggest issue for my son.  But the fact that friends his age didn't bat an eyelid at my exotic range of headscarves seemed to help him forget.   And on Monday I eventually got a wig even though I hope my hair will be back in the autumn.  I didn't do cold cap because I didn't want to have to deal with anything else on top of the chemo.  And my hair was never very thick anyway.  I wish now I'd gone for a wig at the outset because I would've looked as normal as possible for my son.  But again, I had this notion that wigs would be uncomfortable and hot.  In fact I'm finding the one I've got really quite comfortable and helps me feel 'normal'.  I also wear a little 'nightcap' I bought from a website called amoena which specialises in mastectomy/chemo items.  So, my son has only once seen me without anything on my head.  Oh - and I did have my shoulder length hair cut very short just before chemo started.  Now that was traumatic!!  But longer term it helped when it started falling out - less to deal with. So, if your hair does go, could you work out a plan B?  Maybe start looking at wigs?  I've gone blond! And everybody is saying 'wow, suits you!'  Even my ex-partner who doesn't mince his words.... Re chemo; FEC was certainly the most difficult for me.  Not that Tax was without its problems but first dose of FEC absolutely floored me and I felt so ill.  Onc reduced subsequent doses by 20% it was that bad.  If you want to know more about Tax, just say but it is absolutely true that people respond to these drugs differently.  As for holidays, is there any chance you could book something for when you get through the chemo at Centre Parcs or Bluestone park in Wales for a few days?  Not Gran Canaria I admit but maybe your kids will enjoy that too.  Someone said that as they worked through the chemo, their child got some lego every time a chemo cycle was over.  I started doing a similar thing on a very small scale for my son too - just little things like moshi monsters arriving from amazon etc. Anyway, must dash.  Hope you're ok and able to enjoy the w/end.  Take care Anne-Marie x
Posts.Title: For anyone about to start or going through chemo.....

Posts.Content: Hi Sharon My son was a hair twiddler too. In fact, even up to about age 6 he'd still stroke it for comfort.  He was really worried about the hair loss but he's grown use to it and looking forward to my hair coming back..  But it must be so hard to explain to a 4yr old.   I'm sure you will have thought of this already, but can I make a suggestion in case you haven't?  You mentioned having your husband and older children helping out while you're in chemo.  Could you get them to consider how they would manage to run the house, plan food and support the younger children on the basis of you being out of action for 2 weeks out of every 3?  As you've very young children, it might be helpful to assume this in order to make sure so many things are covered, particularly when young children are so dependent.   I say this not to scare you but because I had absolutely no idea how I would respond to the chemo and was pretty naive.  I tried to brave it out and got a hell of a shock when the first dose absolutely floored me. And despite my son's father's best efforts, there were still a number of things I had to cover that he couldn't anticipate because we hadn't planned or talked about it.  I managed better on the 2nd drug, Docetaxol and was up and about much more but it was still tiring.   Hope you don't think I'm interfering but I really sympathise with you having such young children.  Fingers crossed it's all straight forward for you. Take care. Anne-Marie x
Posts.Title: For anyone about to start or going through chemo.....

Posts.Content: Ethel - Have the most wonderful happy holiday with your son!  You both deserve it so much  - as does your sister by all accounts.  That's great you're taking 4 weeks - an opportunity to relax during the holiday rather than thinking you've got to make the most of every day before the hols run out. I'm packing too for Scotland.  Taking my son to stay with my sister and her kids for few days, then caravan by the coast.  I'm then going to brave the Edinburgh festival for a couple of days.  Booked a couple of kids shows for my son and niece and of course then there's all the activities in the streets.  I will tired but very happy to be doing this before rads mid- Aug. Look forward to hearing about holiday when you get back.  Wishing you happy days! Anne-Marie x
Posts.Title: For anyone about to start or going through chemo.....

Posts.Content: Hi Sandy.  thanks for replying.  Would you mind if I asked a couple of questions? - How long did you feel you were susceptible to sunlight?  Was it just during the Tax cycles or for a long period afterwards?  One nurse has told me that I need to take care for up to 2 years! - Was it a gradual process or did your skin recover quickly once Tax stopped?   - Did you use any particular skin cream or sun protection lotion?  It's interesting that yesterday evening the skin on my upper chest started to prickle again.  I haven't been outside or exposed to direct sunlight for a couple of weeks now.  But, I am on the 8th day since receiving 2nd Tax and have just completed 7 day course of injections to boost white cells. It's an almost identical repeat of timetable when the rash started appearing after the first dose of Tax. Ho hum....will just be spending a bit more time indoors watching Wimbledon!  And shopping online for big hats..... Hope you're well.  Many thanks Anne-Marie
Posts.Title: Tax and side effects...esp sunlight?

Posts.Content: Hi Kate.  Thanks for getting back to me.  Just laying low in the house at the moment as determined to get to the final chemo without a hospital visit inbetween!  But will certainly call nurses if flares up again. Best wishes Anne-Marie
Posts.Title: Tax and side effects...esp sunlight?

Posts.Content: Hi everyone, Just wondered if anyone else has experienced the following?  A few days after 1st cycle of docetaxol, I had a mouth infection.  Thought it was oral thrush but Doc said fungal and was prescribed flucanazole.  Within a couple of days of starting that, I had an itchy rash on my chest.  I - stupidly - also sat out on our patio for about 30 to 40 mins taking a phone call while the sun was shining.  Was feeling very exhausted and just glad to have a bit of light. Rash started to spread on my hands and forearms quickly, as well as face.  Went back to hospital and doc said to stop flucanazole straight away.  Rash continued.  Went back couple of days later and was given steriods and type of piriton to calm flaming skin.  Went back the following day to hospital as skin was now incredibly itchy and lips swollen.  Was given much stronger anti-histamine for 7 days.   I should also add that I was taking injections to boost white-blood cells at same time.   Skin did calm down over a few days.  I stayed indoors and weather was dull.  Last Saturday, however, thinking the coast was clear, I took my son to the local park for an hour.  I was wrapped up with scarf, hat, sunglasses, gloves, coat with collar up, long trousers.  Looked very attractive - not!  It wasn't sunny but kept my back to where the sun would've have been as much as possible. Well, that evening my skin went bananas again.  I was up all night with ice packs and cold cloths.  Lips swelled really badly this time - like a nightmarish botox job!  Skin was on fire with itchy pinpricks and tongue swollen too.  Was back in hospital 9am the following morning.  Even the Onc said he didn't recognise me this time.  Was kept in for observation, given extra steriods and managed to get through 2nd chemo cycle the following day. Onc is at loss to understand cause of allergic reaction.  I'm not normally allergic to any foods or medicines.  TAX isn't normally associated with reactions to sunlight although I have since read of one study in the US stating a woman suffered skin allergy after tanning and on TAX.  I'm now housebound!  Might try outing on very dull days with factor 50.  But very interested to know if anyone has had similar side effects and what you did about it.  Didn't have this problem on FEC.  Still difficult time but that's another story! Hope everyone is ok and enjoying the warmer weather more than I am! Many thanks Anne-Marie x
Posts.Title: Tax and side effects...esp sunlight?

Posts.Content: Hi Nicola I developed a very bad itchy rash after receiving Tax and there was - in my case - a definite connection between sunlight and the chemo.  I didn't experience any skin problems with FEC (altho plenty of other side effects!) so I had to put the rash down to Tax. Rash covered my face, hands and feet - areas that had been exposed when I sat out in the sun for 30mins a few days after receiving the first Tax. My approach was to stay out of the sun or cover up as much as possible, use only aquaeous cream on skin, drink loads of water.  It got so bad a couple of times I ended up back in hospital where the doctors prescribed further steriods to keep the reaction to a minimum.  But it was a very tough time and so exhausting as difficult to sleep or rest with itching - like pinpricks stabbing the skin. My face and hands swelled up a bit but my lips looked like they'd been through a really bad botox job.  Very swollen. I'm a month post chemo and now in radiotherapy.  I apply factor 50 to my face everyday under make-up.  I didn't put the cream on my hands the other day and - hey presto! rash appeared but was less severe this time. I was - and still am - surprised this reaction to Tax came as a surprise to the oncs!  My senior onc reckoned the skin should no longer be affected after about 6 weeks post chemo.  A nurse, however, told me the skin can be affected for a couple of years!!! Don't know if this is in any way similar to your circumstances but if you've any questions, do get in touch.  Hope you're near the end of chemo! All the best Anne-Marie
Posts.Title: Docetaxel/Cyclophosamide

Posts.Content: Hi Sorry to hear you're in such discomfort.  Do you think the area has blistered?  I too was advised to use only aqueous cream, drink loads of water and wear very light cotton clothing for a while.  My skin continued to react for several weeks after the rads.  8 months later I still apply a basic cream to the area every day.  In the morning get in touch with your bcn or gp.  They are there to give us reassurance as well as meds! Anne-Marie x
Posts.Title: Radiotherapy - Help please

Posts.Content: Hi Rosalyn Really sorry to hear you've had a such tough time.  It must be very scary to think that you might be at risk of further infection.  I had FEC reduced by 20% after the first dose last year.  And I think all subsequent doses of FEC & Tax were reduced too.  The lead oncologist was not happy about this but it was suggested by another doctor when I was taken back to hospital a couple of days after the first FEC barely conscious.  I just could not stay awake, felt awful and developed a very bad urine infection (no idea if related but it was not a good time.) I by no means sailed through the rest of the chemo.  It was tough.  And the question lurked in my mind - what if I wasn't giving the chemo my best shot by taking a weaker dose?   But then a friend of a friend who's an oncologist told me that a) an 80% dose is still a pretty big amount to hit the cancer with b) it was far better that I continue and complete the chemo than give up. It sounds to me that you need to have a frank conversation with your onc team and possibly take someone with you to take notes.  You've come so far that the end of chemo is in sight.  I've no idea how to stop neutropenic sepsis - not a medic. But I had injections to keep my white blood count up, took a spoon of high grade manuka honey every day, which is supposed to support the immune system, and drank buckets of water. Good luck Rosalyn.  Take a deep breath and keep going.... Anne-Marie xx
Posts.Title: dosetaxel

Posts.Content: Hi Lizane I'm with everyone else who's replied to you....Please stop work right now.  I'm hopefully on my final chemo (3FEC & 3 TAX) Monday and I have to tell you, if I get it without any delay, I will be so relieved....and actually quite chuffed.  I've had various unexpected and difficult side-effects from the chemo at different stages and I don't work with kids!  But you will feel this too - you just want to keep going and get on to the next chemo with as little hassle or delay as possible.  The risk of infection is incredibly high and you really do not want to start off chemo  with a stint in hospital.  I really don't mean to scare you - but protecting yourself is number 1.  Please please remember this. Big hugs for the road ahead. Anne-Marie x p.s. Had 9 lymph nodes removed.  Chemo hasn't interfered with healing but haven't been able to do exercises sometimes if flat out with chemo.  Arm then tends to play up a bit so motto is, exercise the arm. p.p.s was absolutely traumatised before going to mastectomy.  But turned out recovery from it was a doddle, seriously.  Fingers crossed will be for you too.
Posts.Title: About to start chemo .a question or two..?...

Posts.Content: Hi there. I too had a very difficult experience last year.  It was particularly when I took docetaxol.  Exhausted I stupidly sat outside for about 20 mins in sunshine speaking on the phone.  No sunscreen.  Well I paid for it - skin became incredibly sensitive to light and very very itchy, lips swollen and distorted, hands and feet were affected too. Had a couple of trips to hospital for extra steriods and antihistamines when it got so bad.   I ended up staying indoors for the rest of the chemo (about 7 weeks), heading out after dark for a trip round the local tesco when no-one else was around to see me! I used kids sensitive factor 50 continuously for the rest of the year.  My skin is now back to normal and there are no marks.  But I'll be taking a lot more care this year - and the next.... So PLEASE protect yourselves.  I don't know why there isn't more information about this.  I guess not everyone is affected. Take care Anne-Marie x
Posts.Title: SUNSHINE!

Posts.Content: Oh Kiera honey - big hugs.  Not only has your body changed but your life is going to have to as well - i.e. without bf by the sounds of it.  This is when we have to dig really really deep in ourselves to find strength, resolve and do what is good for us - and b%£^er the rest of them who don't support, who run away and think only of themselves.   I promise you one day he will not feel good about himself, he will feel guilt and he will wonder how on earth you have managed to be so strong, picked up your life and moved on.  There's nothing more curious than seeing someone who's looking great and smiling.  I know.  It's happened to me. And I promise you another thing - there are guys out there who are hooked on the woman they love and admire them, particularly for what they've gone through, not just for a boob! Be good to yourself, get the make-up on and get out.  Hope you've got some good girlfriends around - if not, talk to us. Take care AM x (currently with one very small 32a boob!)
Posts.Title: I can't cope anymore

Posts.Content: Angel you don't know it's going to be a head 'fuck'.  People react very differently to the chemo treatment.  Some manage it well, others less so.  But I can tell you this - booze ain't going to help and if anything it will make the situation worse for you. I've looked at your profile.  You're young and clearly very fit, running a 10k.  You've brought up kids which is no mean feat.  You have grandchildren to love. And you are a fighter. Can you put your finger on exactly are you scared of?  We can help here with information, advice and support.  But at some point that fighting spirit of yours is going to have to come out with massive gloves on.  It's time to take some control of what is about to happen to you.  So, 1.  Practical preparation.  Start drinking lots of water. Have you got a good thermometer?  Who is going to accompany you to the sessions?  Have you decided if you're going for a wig or using scarves and hats? etc etc etc 2. Plan good things to do.  Things you really want to do.  Ok world cruise is out of the question.  But Marg here threw a party.  I booked a holiday for the end of chemo in a caravan with my son, my sister and her family.  Shop til you drop. Watch Channing Tatum in the scuddy.  Whatever works for you.... Get back in the driving seat Angel.  This is might not what you want to hear at the moment but you've said you're a fighter and now is the time to fight your fears and your nerves.  Last year forced me to dig really really deep to keep calm and keep going. So it can be done. Hope the sun is shining for you today.  Anne-Marie x
Posts.Title: I feel Shellshocked.

Posts.Content: Hi Gail.  I've just completed 15 rads and no smelling.  Not that my sense of smell is great but, like you, I would've noticed. Have you mentioned this to the rads team?  Mine were brilliant.  Good briefing before it all started, weekly chats about how it was going.  Hope yours are approachable - it's so helpful to be able to talk. Sorry can't be more help but good luck. Anne-Marie x
Posts.Title: Radiotherapy and underarm is smelling

Posts.Content: Hi. Thanks so much for this tip.  I was bitten the other day although not on the affected arm but it did make me wonder about insect repellent.  I've just been on the Avon website and there seems to be 2 products: Skin So Soft Silky Moisture Dry Oil Body Spray Skin So Soft Original Dry Oil Spray Do you use a particular one or both do the job?   Many thanks Anne-Marie
Posts.Title: Lymphodema risk and insect repellent

Posts.Content: Hi Emma, I may not know you but I just want to send you a very very big hug. Anne-Marie x
Posts.Title: It's Back! And this time it's...

Posts.Content: oh marg that's lovely!  your granddaughter stroking your head.... my son loved stroking my hair when he was little. such a comforting thing to do.  He was really worried when he found out I was losing my hair last year.  But the great thing about kids is how quickly they move on. Anne-Marie x
Posts.Title: Hair worries

Posts.Content: Hi there. I'm sorry to hear that you are feeling so low.  Believe me - and you will see from the posts here - you are not alone in feeling as you do.  There are plenty of us who have really difficult times. Friends/no friends, partners/deserters, guilt cos cancer wasn't that serious/cancer very serious etc etc. If there's one thing I learned last year when going through the whole treatment is that actually we really are often truly alone.  And we need to be so so strong to deal with the terror of the diagnosis, the physical pain of the arduous treatment and the enormous upheavel to our lives. Whether you have family and friends around you or not, it's you who has to deal with cancer head on.  Yes the media can distort the truth but last year I came across an article in the Huffington Post titled Nobody Shaved Their Head for Me.  It talked about the different stages friends/family go through when hearing of your diagnosis; from rallying round frantically to silence.  And I personally identified with what the author said.  It made me feel someone out there understood the isolation, the resentment about the situation I found myself in, the disappointment of 'friends' and  the hard slog to get through the treatment. So how to respond to cancer and its impact on our lives?  I can't presume to tell you what to do.  The one thing I would say is, it seems to me there's been a lot in your life affecting the way you are feeling now - and it's not just your breast.  But where to begin?  Ironically, for some people dealing with cancer has forced them to have a damn good look at their lives and figure out what they don't want anymore.  In your situation, is it being on your own?  Other good folks will respond to you with their thoughts.  I hope you are able to take heart from the group here and even possibly start responding to some who are desperate.  You say you've had an 'unconventional' life.  That to me reads 'interesting' life.  I'd like to hear more about it and I bet some of your life experiences might at some point help others. Take care.  Keep in touch. Anne-Marie x
Posts.Title: Alone, getting older, defeated. ..

Posts.Content: Hi Susie You might have this already for your daughter but just wanted to add that when my son had chicken pox a year ago, a cream called ViraSoothe really helped him......and helped us all get some sleep! Glad you're on the mend after mastectomy.  I found recovering from it easier than a previous op. Take care and keep going! Anne-Marie x
Posts.Title: New diagnosis - Scared and loosing faith in the system fast

Posts.Content: Hi Flower Totally understand how you're feeling.  I'm still up, find it difficult to go to bed, had some pretty dark times early in the morning.  However, I'm a bit ahead of you as had diagnosis in January and can tell that it's amazing how the human mind takes in all this trauma and you still keep moving forward.  And the guilt is a really difficult thing.  Sometimes I want to reach out - like now because I'm feeling stronger and hope I can pass on a hug and some support at the very least.  Other times though, I just can't face it and can only read what other people are going through.  This is absolutely normal Flower - so don't worry about it.  Good luck with your family - they must stick together, particularly through the wobbly moments.  My son is only 7 and even though I've tried so hard to make sure he's busy and happy, there's been wobbly, worrying moments with him too.   Hugs and peaceful times together and having a laugh are so so important (i even left the dishes in the sink earlier tonight to watch a dvd with him - they're still there!) Hope you have a more peaceful night.  Big hugs to you too. Anne-Marie xx
Posts.Title: Feeling Guilty Now

Posts.Content: p.s. meant to add...... you must all indulge in good food!! Keep your energy up and health good. Spoil yourselves!  but maybe skip the booze..... although I am soon hoping to set a date with a bottle of champagne. AMx
Posts.Title: Feeling Guilty Now

Posts.Content: Hi there.  As everyone has already said, this is a real life roller coaster.  It has depths of despair and highs of great joy but Orangetulip...there is no surrender.   And you're in really good company here with people who do truly understand and care so please keep in touch and don't feel at a complete loss. I've got some spare china if you need it!  When I got my diagnosis at the beginning of the year, the nurse took me to a private room to get my head around the news - well, I started kicking the furniture really hard and swearing my head off.  I'm not inclined to lots of expletives but I was so mad as this year was supposed to be when I had a new start at so many things in my life after an incredibly stressful period.  So honey, every time we get tripped up, let's pick ourselves as best we can and get the lipstick on. Take care Anne-Marie x
Posts.Title: I don't know what to say now

Posts.Content: Hi Since treatment last year I've had sinus infection after sinus infection.  Think our bodies are a bit hammered and immune systems weakened.  I've had antibiotics and did help for a while so pls do see your doc.  I'm thinking about anti flu jabs in winter and going back to a high strength manuka honey to see that helps with overall health.  Hope cough clears up soon. Anne-Marie x
Posts.Title: Coughing

Posts.Content: Hi Caroline I'm no medical help at all but you sound so isolated in France.  I'm sure it's not the case (have lived there too)  but I just wanted to acknowledge your post and let you know people here are reading you.   That said your temperature is still on the high side.  Can you not just turn up at an A&E anyway and ask to be checked?  I know the health system there is different but it is good and they must be able to respond to situations like yours. Keep in touch.  Anne-Marie x
Posts.Title: Freaking out slightly
